docs.snippet: There is a side of Oscar De La Hoya that hasn't been seen. The De La Hoya who talks about getting hurt in the ring, about having to take a knee during a bout. The boxer who talks about whether it is nobler to stand and sling punches, or stay out o...
docs.lead_paragraph: There is a side of Oscar De La Hoya that hasn't been seen. The De La Hoya who talks about getting hurt in the ring, about having to take a knee during a bout. The boxer who talks about whether it is nobler to stand and sling punches, or stay out of harm's way. De La Hoya shared those thoughts with reporters today as he talked about fighting Ike Quartey on Saturday at the Thomas and Mack Arena in a 12-round bout for De La Hoya's World Boxing Council welterweight championship. The bout will be broadcast on pay-per-view by TVKO.
docs.abstract: Oscar De La Hoya discusses his preparations to defend his World Boxing Council welterweight championship against Ike Quartey (M)

headline.main: De La Hoya Plays Hamlet As He Waits for Quartey

docs.snippet: A hallmark of our time is the way every artifact or event, no matter how trivial, turns into an assessment of where and who we are. A week after the groundhog visits his shadow, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences releases its Oscar no...
docs.lead_paragraph: A hallmark of our time is the way every artifact or event, no matter how trivial, turns into an assessment of where and who we are. A week after the groundhog visits his shadow, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences releases its Oscar nominations, which lie before us now like so many tea leaves. The question is not whether Tom Hanks can win the best actor award one more time, but what it would say about us if he did. Does the pattern of nominations -- ''Shakespeare in Love'' trumping ''Saving Private Ryan,'' Jim Carrey going wholly unmentioned -- reflect the sour, shameful mood of a nation burdened by an impeachment trial? Or does it capture the powerful surge of our economy, the flood tide of job creation, and optimism over a long-lasting boom? There is a tendency to read these nominations as if they were the results of a nationwide poll, a more impartial verdict on the state of the union than the President was able to deliver when he appeared before Congress last month. But how can that verdict be accurate when ''There's Something About Mary'' -- one of the year's most popular if moronic films -- is up for nothing?
docs.abstract: Editorial scoffs at tendency to read too much social significance into Oscar nominations

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-17    Pentagon Questioning Risks and Goals in Kosovo  Senior Pentagon officials are raising serious concerns about sending American troops into Kosovo without clear-cut military goals, even as NATO contemplates sending peacekeep...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Pentagon Questioning Risks and Goals in Kosovo Senior Pentagon officials are raising serious concerns about sending American troops into Kosovo without clear-cut military goals, even as NATO contemplates sending peacekeepers there. A9 The toughest arguments of the Kosovo peace conference so far have been among the hosts, not the Albanian and Serbian delegates. A8

docs.snippet: Maybe directors and screenwriters are finally struggling with grand historical themes. Perhaps filmmakers in their 50's are looking back at the defining events of their childhood. But in an unusual turn, World War II dominated the nominations toda...
docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe directors and screenwriters are finally struggling with grand historical themes. Perhaps filmmakers in their 50's are looking back at the defining events of their childhood. But in an unusual turn, World War II dominated the nominations today for the 71st annual Academy Awards. Three films dealing with the war -- ''Saving Private Ryan,'' ''The Thin Red Line'' and ''Life Is Beautiful'' -- were among the five nominated for best picture. The other two, about one other era of history, were ''Elizabeth'' and ''Shakespeare in Love.'' In addition ''The Last Days,'' about Holocaust survivors recalling their lives in the camps, was one of five nominees for best documentary.

docs.snippet: ''As you approach the millennium you think of the defining events of the century. And World War II was one of them, particularly for filmmakers who didn't go through it but see it, in one way or another, as influencing the world we've lived in.'' ...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''As you approach the millennium you think of the defining events of the century. And World War II was one of them, particularly for filmmakers who didn't go through it but see it, in one way or another, as influencing the world we've lived in.'' LAURA ZISKIN, president of Fox 2000, after three films about World War II received Oscar nominations for best picture. [E1]

docs.snippet: Hector Alejandro Galindo Amezcua, a prolific film director who created his own genre of movies set in Mexico's urban underworld, died on Feb. 1. He was 93.    Mr. Galindo, who was known in the Mexican film world as Don Alex, directed or wrote scri...
docs.lead_paragraph: Hector Alejandro Galindo Amezcua, a prolific film director who created his own genre of movies set in Mexico's urban underworld, died on Feb. 1. He was 93. Mr. Galindo, who was known in the Mexican film world as Don Alex, directed or wrote scripts for more than 70 films, virtually all of them made in Mexico. He was one of the directors, along with Emilio Fernandez, who pioneered a booming film industry in Mexico in the 1940's and 50's based on movies that portrayed the travails and heartbreak of workaday Mexicans.

headline.main: Hector Alejandro Galindo, Mexican Film Director, 93

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-11    German Holocaust Fund Is Approved in Principle  The German Government said it had agreed in principle to establish a compensation fund, financed by the biggest names in German industry and banking, for victims of Nazi horr...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 German Holocaust Fund Is Approved in Principle The German Government said it had agreed in principle to establish a compensation fund, financed by the biggest names in German industry and banking, for victims of Nazi horrors. The proposal appears to be an effort to short-circuit a wave of lawsuits in American courts. A10

docs.snippet: From a fashion point of view, which is the only one on Seventh Avenue, the autumn shows taking place this week and next on the tented lawn at Bryant Park are already two sandwiches shy of a picnic. It isn't that anyone expects to have fun: there a...
docs.lead_paragraph: From a fashion point of view, which is the only one on Seventh Avenue, the autumn shows taking place this week and next on the tented lawn at Bryant Park are already two sandwiches shy of a picnic. It isn't that anyone expects to have fun: there are more than 75 men's and women's shows on the official roster, some 25 others in SoHo and Chelsea, and that means . . . what? . . . 8,000 outfits to be absorbed before all the hoopla ends a week from Friday. As Michael Kors said the other day in a tone heavy with fatigue: ''I feel like the Dunkin' Donut man. Time to make the fashions.'' In fact, what really keeps the spectacle from being a glamorous event -- full of models, clothes, celebrities, editors racing around like Shriners -- is the question of whether anyone will make money. That has always been the unabashed, undisguised goal of Seventh Avenue, making money. But these days, with Isaac Mizrahi out of business, fashion stocks in the dumps and pink slips at Ralph Lauren, it is almost a taboo subject.
docs.abstract: Article describes preparations for New York City fashion week; photo (M)

headline.main: Before the Shows, Eavesdropping on Seventh Avenue
